&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than any Roman did her a dishonor.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Has not Lucretia slain herself, alas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; At Rome, when she was raped<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; By Tarquin, for she thought it was a shame<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To live when she had lost her good name?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The seven maidens of Miletus also<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Have slain themselves, for sheer dread and woe,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Rather than folk of Galatia should rape them.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; More than a thousand stories, as I guess,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Could I now tell concerning this matter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When Habradate was slain, his wife so dear<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Herself slew, and let her blood pour<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In Habradate's wounds deep and wide,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, `My body, at the least,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There shall no person defile, if I can (help it)."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Why should I tell more examples concerning this,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Since so many have themselves slain<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Well rather than they would be defiled?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I will conclude that it is better for me<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To slay myself than be defiled thus.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I will be true unto Arveragus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or rather slay myself in some manner,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As did Demotion's daughter dear<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Because she would not defiled be.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; O Scedasus, it is a very great pity<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To read how thy daughters died, alas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who slew themselves for a similar sort of cause.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As great a pity was it, or well more,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The Theban maiden that for Nichanore<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Slew herself, exactly for such sort of woe.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Another Theban maiden did exactly the same;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Because one of Macedonia had raped her,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She with her death avenged her maidenhood.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; What shall I say of Nicerates' wife,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That for a similar case deprived herself of her life?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; How true also to Alcebiades was<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His lover, who chose rather to die <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than to allow his body to be unburied.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Lo, what a wife was Alcestis," she said.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "What says Homer of good Penelope?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; All Greece knows of her chastity.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; By God, of Laodomia is written thus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That when at Troy Protheselaus was slain,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; No longer would she live after his day (i.e., death).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The same of noble Portia I can tell;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Without Brutus she could not live,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To whom she had entirely given her heart.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The perfect wifehood of Arthemesie<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Honored is through all heathendom.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; O Teuta, queen, thy wifely chastity<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To all wives may be a mirror.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The same thing I say of Bilia,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of Rhodogune, and also Valeria."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thus Dorigen complained a day or two,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Intending ever that she would die.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But neverthelees, upon the third night,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Home came Arveragus, this worthy knight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And asked her why she wept so bitterly;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And she began to weep, ever the longer (she wept) the more (she wept) . <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Alas," said she, "that ever I was born!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thus have I said," said she, "thus have I sworn" --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And told him all as you have heard before;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There is no need to repeat it to you any more.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This husband, with cheerful demeanor, in a friendly manner<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Answered and said as I shall tell you:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Is there anything else, Dorigen, but this?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Nay, nay," she said, "So help me God!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This is too much, even if it were God's will."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Yes, wife," he said, "let sleep that which is still.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It may be well, perhaps, yet to day.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; You shall keep your pledged word, by my faith!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For as surely as God may have mercy upon me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I had well rather be stabbed <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For sheer love which I to have for you,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than you should (do anything but) keep and save your pledged word.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; One's pldged word is the highest thing that one may keep" --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But with that word he immediately burst into tears,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "I you forbid, upon pain of death,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That never, while thy life or breath lasts,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou tell any person about this adventure --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As I best can, I will my woe endure --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nor make any outward appearance of sadness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That folk may believe or guess anything harmful concerning you."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And forth he called a squire and a maid:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Go forth right now with Dorigen," he said,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "And bring her to such a place quickly."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; They take their leave, and on their way they go,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But they knew not why she thither went.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He would no person tell his intention.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Perhaps a heap of you, indeed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Will consider him a foolish man in this<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That he will put his wife in jeopardy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Listen to the tale before you cry out about her.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She may have better fortune than it seems to you;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And when you have heard the tale, judge.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This squire, who was called Aurelius,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; On Dorigen who was so amorous,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; By chance happened to meet her <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Amidst the town, right in the busiest street,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As she was about to go the way directly<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Toward the garden where she had promised (to go).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he was going toward the garden also;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For well he spied when she would go<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Out of her house to any sort of place.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But thus they met, by chance or luck,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he salutes her cheerfully,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And asked her where she went;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And she answered, as if she were half mad,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Unto the garden, as my husband commanded,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; My pledged word to keep -- alas, alas!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Aurelius began to wonder about this case,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And in his heart had great compassion<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of her and of her lamentation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And of Arveragus, the worthy knight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who commanded her to keep all that she had promised,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So hateful to him it was that his wife should break her word;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And in his heart he took great pity on this,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Considering what would be best in every respect,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That he would rather yet refrain from his desire<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than do so great a churlish despicable act<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Against generosity and all nobility of character;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For which in few words he said thus:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Madam, say to your lord Arveragus<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That since I see his great graciousness<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To you, and also I see well your distress,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That he would rather have shame (and that would be a pity)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than you should thus break your pledged word to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I would well rather suffer woe always<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than I should break apart the love between you two.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I release you, madam, into your hand I return<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Freely every pledge and every bond<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That you have made to me before now,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Since that time when you were born.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I pledge my word, I shall never reprove you <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For any promise, and here I take my leave,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of the truest and the best wife<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That ever yet I knew in all my life.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But let every wife beware of her promise!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Remember Dorigen, at the least.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thus can a squire do a gentle deed<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As well as can a knight, without doubt."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She thanks him upon her bare knees,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And home unto her husband she is gone,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And told him all, as you have heard me say;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And be you sure, he was so well pleased<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That it would be impossible for me to write.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Why should I write longer about this matter?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Arveragus and Dorigen his wife<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In perfect bliss lead forth their life.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Never again was there any anger between them.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He cherishes her as though she were a queen,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And she was to him true for evermore.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of these two folk you get of me no more.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Aurelius, that all his expenditure has forfeited,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Curses the time that ever he was born:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Alas!" said he. "Alas, that I promised<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of refined gold a thousand pounds of weight<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Unto this scientist! What shall I do?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I see no more but that I am ruined.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; My heritage I must of necessity sell,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And be a beggar; here I may not remain<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And shame all my kin in this place,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Unless I can get a better grace (favor) from him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But nonetheless, I will try him, (offering)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; At specific days, year by year, to pay,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And thank him for his great courtesy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; My word I will keep, I will not lie."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; With a sore heart he goes unto his money box,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And brought gold unto this scientist,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The value of five hundred pounds, I guess,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And him beseeches, of his nobleness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To grant him days (on which to pay) the remnant;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Master, I dare well make boast,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I failed never of my pledged word as yet.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For surely my debt shall be repaid<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To you, even though I have<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To go a-begging in my bare tunic.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But if you would agree, upon my promise,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To grant me a respite for two years or three,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Then I would be well; for otherwise I must sell<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; My heritage; there is no more to tell."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This scientist soberly answered,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said thus, when he heard these words:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Have I not kept my agreement with thee?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Yes, certainly, well and truly," said he.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Hast thou not had thy lady as it pleases thee?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "No, no," said he, and sorrowfully he sighs.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "What was the cause? Tel me if thou know how."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Aurelius his tale immediately began,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And told him all, as you have heard before;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There is no need to repeat it to you again.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He said, "Arveragus, of his nobility,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Had rather die in sorrow and in distress<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than that his wife would be false of her pledged word."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The sorrow of Dorigen he told him also;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; How loathfull to her it was to be a wicked wife,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And that she would rather have lost her life that day,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And that her word she swore through ignorance,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She never before had heard tell of illusion.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "That made me have for her such great pity;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And right as freely as he sent her to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As freely I sent her to him again.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This is the entire matter; there is no more to say."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This scientist answered, "Dear brother,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Every one of you did nobly to the other.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou art a squire, and he is a knight;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But God forbid, for his blissful might,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That a clerk could not do a gentle deed <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As well as any of you, it is no doubt!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Sir, I release thee from thy (debt of a) thousand pounds,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As if thou right now were crept out of the ground,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nor never before now had known me.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For, sir, I will not take a penny from thee<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For all my craft, nor anything for my labor.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou hast paid well for my living expenses.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It is enough, and farewell, have good day!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And took his horse, and forth he goes his way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Gentlemen, this question, then, will I ask now,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Which was the most free, as it seems to you?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Now tell me, before you farther go.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I know no more; my tale is at an end.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Great was the feast in Athens that day,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also the pleasing season of that May<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Made every person to be in such delight<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That all that Monday they joust and dance,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And spend that day in Venus's noble service.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But because they must rise<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Early, to see the great fight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unto their rest they went at nightfall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in the morning, when day did spring,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Noise and clattering of horses and armor <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was in hostelries all about,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to the palace there rode many a company<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of lords upon steeds and palfreys.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There canst thou see preparation of armor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So exotic and so rich, and wrought so well<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of goldsmiths' works, of embroidery, and of steel;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The bright shields, horses' head-armor, and horse-armor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Gold-colored helms, coats of mail, tunics with heraldic devices; <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Lords in richly decorated robes on their coursers,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Knights of  (their) retinues, and also squires<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nailing heads to the spear-shafts, and buckling helms;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fitting the shields with straps, fastening with laces --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Where it is needed they were not at all idle;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The steeds frothing on the golden bridles<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Gnawing, and fast the armorers also<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With file and hammer are spurring to and fro;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Yeomen on foot, and foot soldiers many a one<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With short staves, thick as they can go;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Pipes, trumpets, kettle drums, bugles,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That blow bloody sounds in the battle;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The palace full of people everywhere,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Here three, there ten, debating, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Conjecturing about these two Theban knights.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some said thus, some said "it shall be so";<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some held with him with the black beard,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some with the bald, some with the thickly haired;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some said he looked grim, and he would fight:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"He has a battle-ax of twenty pounds of weight."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Thus was the hall full of conjecturing,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Long after the sun began to rise.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The great Theseus, who was awakened of his sleep<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By the music and noise that was made,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Remained yet in the chamber of his rich palace <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Until the Theban knights, both equally<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Honored, were fetched into the palace.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Duke Theseus was set at a window,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Arrayed exactly as if he were a god on a throne.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The people press thither full soon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In order to see him, and to do great reverence,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also to hear his command and his decision.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A herald on a scaffold made a "Ho!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Until all the noise of people was done,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And when he saw the people all still of noise,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then showed he the mighty duke's will:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"The lord has of his great sound judgment<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Considered that it would be destruction<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To gentle blood to fight in the manner<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of mortal battle now in this undertaking.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Wherefore, to arrange matters so that they shall not die,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He will modify his previous plan.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;No man therefore, upon punishment of loss of life,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;No sort of arrow, nor battle-axe, nor short knife<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Send into the lists or bring there;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor short sword, to stab with piercing point,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;May no man neither draw, nor bear it by his side.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And no man shall ride at his opponent<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;More than one course with a sharply honed spear; <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Let him thrust, if he wishes, on foot, to defend himself.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he who is at a disadvantage shall be taken<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And not slain, but be brought unto the stake<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That shall be placed on either side;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But thither he must (go) by force, and remain there.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if so happen that the chieftain be taken<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;On either side, or else should slay his opponent,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The tournament shall last no longer.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;God give you success! Go forth and lay on fast!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With long sword and with mace fight your fill.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Go now on your way; this is the lord's will."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The voice of people touched the heaven,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So loudly they cried with merry voices,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"God save such a lord, that is so good<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He desires no destruction of blood!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Up go the trumpets and the melody,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to the lists rides the company,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In battle array, throughout all the city, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Hung with cloth of gold, and not with serge.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fully like a lord this noble duke did ride,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;These two Thebans upon either side,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after rode the queen and Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after that another company<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One after another, according to their rank.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thus they pass throughout the city,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And they come to the lists in good time.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It was not yet fully prime (nine a.m.) of the day <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When Theseus was set very splendidly and nobly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Ypolita the queen, and Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And other ladies about in tiers.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unto the seats press all the crowd.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And westward, through the gates under Mars,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Arcite, and also the hundred of his party,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With red banner is entered right away;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in that same moment Palamon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is under Venus, eastward in the place,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With white banner and hardy countenance and face.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all the world, to seek up and down,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So evenly, without variation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There were not two such companies,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For there was no one so wise that could say<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That any one had advantage over the other <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In worthiness, nor in status, nor age,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So evenly were they chosen, as I estimate.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in two fair ranks they arrange themselves.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When every one of their names were read,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So that in their total number there would be no deception,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then the gates were shut, and cried was aloud:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Do now your duty, proud young knights!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The heralds left their spurring up and down;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now trumpets and bugles ring loud. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There is no more to say, but from west and east<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In go the spears very firmly in the lance-rests;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In goes the sharp spur into the flank.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There people see who can joust and who can ride;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There splinter spears upon thick shields;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He feels the stabbing through the breast-bone.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Up spring spears twenty foot on height;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out go the swords bright as silver;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The helms they hew to pieces and cut into shreds<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out burst the blood in strong red streams;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With mighty maces they break the bones to pieces.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He did thrust through the thickest of the throng;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There strong steeds stumble, and down goes all,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He rolls under foot as does a ball;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;On his feet he stabs with the broken shaft of his spear,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he hurtles him down with his horse;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He is hurt through the body and then taken,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Despite all he can do, and brought unto the stake;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As was the agreement, right there he must abide.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Another on that other side is led away.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And for a while Theseus makes them rest,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To refresh themselves and drink, if they wish.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Many times these two Thebans have  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Met together, and (each) wrought woe to his opponent;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Each has unhorsed the other of them two.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was not any tiger in the vale of Gargaphia, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When her whelp is stolen when it is little,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So cruel on the hunt as is Arcite<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For jealous heart upon this Palamon.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor in Benmarin there is not so fierce a lion,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is hunted, or maddened by his hunger,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor of his prey desires so the blood,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As Palamon to slay his foe Arcite.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The fervent strokes bite on their helms;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out runs red blood on both their sides.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some time there is an end of every deed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For before the sun went unto its rest,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The strong king Emetreus did seize<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This Palamon, as he fought with Arcite,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And made his sword deep in his flesh to bite,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And by the force of twenty he (Palamon) is taken  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Without having surrendered, and dragged to the stake.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in the rescue of this Palamon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The strong king Lygurge is born down,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And king Emetreus, despite all his strength,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is carried out of his saddle a sword's length,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So hit him Palamon before he was taken.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But all for naught; he was brought to the stake.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His hardy heart could not help him:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He must abide, when he was caught,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By force and also by the agreed terms of battle.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who sorrows now but woeful Palamon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That must no more go again to fight?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And when Theseus had seen this sight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unto each one of the folk that fought thus <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He cried, "Stop! no more, for it is done!  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I will be true judge, and no partisan.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Arcite of Thebes shall have Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who by his fortune has won her fairly."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Immediately there is a noise of people begun<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For joy of this, so loud and clamorous indeed<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It seemed that the lists should fall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;What now can fair Venus do above?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;What says she now? What does this queen of love,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But weeps so, for lack of (having) her will,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Until her tears fell in the lists? <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She said, "I am disgraced, doubtless."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Saturn said, "Daughter, hold thy peace!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Mars has his will, his knight has all his request,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And, by my head, thou shalt be relieved soon."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The trumpeters, with the loud music,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The heralds, who full loudly yell and cry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Are in their happiest state for joy of dan Arcite.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But listen to me, and stop the noise for a little,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(Hear) what a miracle at once befell there.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This fierce Arcite has taken off his helm,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And on a war horse, to show his face,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He spurs from one end to the other of the large open space<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Looking upward upon this Emelye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And she to him cast a friendly eye<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(For women, so to speak in general,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;They all follow the favor of Fortune)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And was all his source of pleasure, in his heart.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out of the ground leaped an infernal fury,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Sent from Pluto at the request of Saturn,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which his horse for fear began to turn,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And leaped aside, and stumbled as he leaped;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And before Arcite can take heed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He hit himself on the top of his head,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That in the place he lay as if he were dead,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His breast shattered by his saddlebow.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He lay as black as any coal or crow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The blood was so run in his face.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Immediately he was carried out of the place,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With painful heart, to Theseus's palace.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then was he cut out of his armor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And brought in a bed very gently and quickly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he was yet conscious and alive,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And always crying for Emelye.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Duke Theseus, with all his company,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is come home to Athens, his city,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With all bliss and great solemnity.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Although this accident had happened,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would not distress them all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;People said also that Arcite shall not dye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He shall be healed of his injuries.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And of another thing they were as happy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That of them all there was no one slain,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Although they (were) sorely hurt, and especially one,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Whose breastbone was pierced by a spear.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To other wounds and to broken arms<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some had salves, and some had charms;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Medicines made of herbs, and also of sage<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;They drank, for they wanted to have their limbs cured.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which this noble duke, as he well knows how,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Comforts and honors every man,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And made revel all the long night<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For the foreign lords, as was right.  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor was it considered any defeat (in battle)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But (only) as a joust or a tournament;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For truly there was no defeat.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For falling is nothing but an accident,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor to be led by force unto the stake<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Without having surrendered, and taken by twenty knights,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One person alone, without others,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And dragged forth by arm, foot, and toe,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also his steed driven forth with staves<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By men on foot, both yeomen and also foot soldiers --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He incurred no shameful blame for it; <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; No man there may call it cowardice.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which anon duke Theseus had proclaimed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To put a stop to all rancor and ill-will,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The victory (is given) as well to one side as to the other,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And either side equal as the other's brother; <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And gave them gifts in accordance with their ranks,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And held a feast for fully three days,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And honorably escorted the kings <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out of his town a full day's journey.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And home went every man the direct way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no more but "Fare well, have good day!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of this battle I will write no more,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But speak of Palamon and of Arcite.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The breast of Arcite swells, and the pain<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At his heart increases more and more.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The clotted blood, despite any medical treatment,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Corrupts, and is left in the trunk of his body,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That neither blood letting at a vein, nor applying suction cups,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor drink of herbs can be any help to him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The power expulsive (to expel fluids), or animal,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;From that power called natural<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Can not remove nor expel the poison.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The pipes of his lungs began to swell,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And every muscle down in his breast<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is destroyed by poison and corrupted matter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Avails him neither, to preserve his life,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Vomit upward, nor downward laxative.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All is shattered in that region;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nature now has no power to control. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And certainly, where Nature will not work,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fare well medicine! Go bear the man to church!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This is the whole of it, that Arcite must die;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which he sends after Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And Palamon, who was his dear cousin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then said he thus, as you shall after hear:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"The woeful spirit in my heart can not<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Declare one small part of all my painful sorrows<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To you, my lady, whom I love most,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But I bequeath the service of my ghost<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To you above every creature,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Since my life can no longer endure.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Alas, the woe! Alas, the strong pains,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That I have suffered for you, and so long!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Alas, the death! Alas, my Emelye!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Alas, separation of our company!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Alas, my heart's queen! Alas, my wife,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;My heart's lady, ender of my life!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;What is this world? What do people ask to have?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now with his love, now in his cold grave<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Alone, without any company.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fare well, my sweet foe, my Emelye!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And softly take me in your two arms,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For love of God, and listen to what I say.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"I have here with my cousin Palamon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Had strife and rancor many a day ago<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For love of you, and for my jealousy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And as Jupiter may guide my soul,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To speak specifically of a servant (of love),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With all the attendant attributes truly --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is to say, truth, honor, knighthood,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Wisdom, humbleness, rank, and noble ancestry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nobility of character, and all that belongs to that art --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As Jupiter may have concern for my soul,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In this world right now I know no one<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So worthy to be loved as Palamon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who serves you, and will do so all his life.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if ever you shall be a wife,   <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Forget not Palamon, the gentle man."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And with that word his speech began to fail,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For from his feet up to his breast had come<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The cold of death, which had overcome him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And yet moreover, for in his two arms <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The vital strength is lost and all gone.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Only the intellect, nothing else,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That dwelled in his heart sick and sore,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Began to fail when the heart felt death.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His two eyes grew dark, and his breath failed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But on his lady yet he cast his eye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His last word was, "Mercy, Emelye!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His spirit changed house and went where,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Since I came never (there), I can not tell where.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therefore I stop; I am no theologian;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I find nothing about souls in this register,  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor do I wish to tell such beliefs  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of them, though they write of where they (the souls) dwell.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Arcite is cold, may Mars guide his soul!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now will I speak forth of Emelye.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Emelye shrieked, and Palamon howls,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And Theseus immediately took his sister <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Swooning, and carried her away from the corpse.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;What helps it to waste the whole day<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To tell how she wept both evening and morning?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For in such cases women have such sorrow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When their husbands are gone from them,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That for the most part they so sorrow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or else fall in such illness<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That at the last certainly they die.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Infinite are the sorrows and the tears<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of old folk and folk of tender years<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all the town for the death of this Theban.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For him there weep both child and man;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no such great weeping, certainly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When Hector was brought, just recently slain,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To Troy. Alas, the lamentation that was there,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Scratching of cheeks, also tearing of hair.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Why wouldst thou be dead," these women cry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Since thou haddest gold enough, and Emelye?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;No man might comfort Theseus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Except for his old father Egeus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who knew the changes of this world,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As he had seen it change both up and down,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Joy after woe, and woe after gladness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And showed them examples and comparisons.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Right as there died never a man," said he,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Who did not live in earth to some extent<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Just so there lived never a man," he said,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"In all this world, who some time did not die.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This world is nothing but a thoroughfare full of woe,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And we are pilgrims, passing to and fro.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Death is an end of every worldly pain."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And beyond all this yet he said much more<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To this effect, full wisely to exhort<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The people that they should comfort themselves. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Duke Theseus, with all his careful attention,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Considered now where the tomb<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of good Arcite may best be made,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also most honorable in (regard to) his rank.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And at the last he concluded<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That there where first Arcite and Palamon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Had the battle between them for love,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That in that same grove, sweet-smelling and green, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Where he had his amorous desires,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His lament, and for love his hot fires,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would make a fire in which the rite<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of a funeral he might fully perform.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he ordered immediately to hack and hew<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The old oaks, and lay them in a row<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In piles arranged to burn well.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His officers with swift feet they run<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And ride quickly at his commandment.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after this, Theseus has sent<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For a bier, and it all overspread<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With cloth of gold, the richest that he had.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And of the same material he clad Arcite;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon his hands he had white gloves,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also on his head a crown of green laurel,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in his hand a sword full bright and keen.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He laid him, with the face bare, on the bier;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therewith he wept that it was a pity to hear.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in order that all the people should see him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When it was day, he brought him to the hall,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That resounds with the crying and the sound.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then came this woeful Theban Palamon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With waving beard and rough hair sprinkled with ashes,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In black clothes, all sprinkled with tears;  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And, excelling others in weeping, Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The most pitiful of all the company.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In order that the ritual should be<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The more noble and rich in its degree,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Duke Theseus had three steeds brought forth,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That were equipped with trappings of steel all glittering,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And covered with the coat of arms of Don Arcite.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon these steeds, that were large and white,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There sat folk, of which one carried his (Arcite's) shield,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Another held his spear upright in his hands,  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The third carried with him his Turkish bow<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(Of pure gold was the quiver and also the fittings);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And they rode forth slowly with sorrowful demeanor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Toward the grove, as you shall later hear.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The noblest of the Greeks that were there <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Carried the bier upon their shoulders,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With slow pace and eyes red and wet,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Throughout the city by the main street,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which was all spread with black, and wonderfully high<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The street is covered with exactly the same.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon the right hand went old Egeus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And on that other side duke Theseus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With vessels of pure gold in their hands,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All full of honey, milk, and blood, and wine;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also Palamon, with a very large company;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after that came woeful Emelye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With fire in hand, as was at that time the custom,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To do the office of funeral service.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Much labor and full great preparation <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was at the service and the fire-making,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which with its green top reached the heaven;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And twenty fathom of breadth the sides stretched --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This is to say, the boughs were so broad.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was first laid very many a load of straw.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But how the fire was made on high,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor also the names that the trees are called,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Such as oak, fir, birch, aspen, alder, holm oak, poplar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Willow, elm, plane, ash, box, chestnut, linden, laurel,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Maple, thorn, beech, hazel, yew, dogwood --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;How they were cut down shall not be told by me;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how the gods ran up and down,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Disinherited of their habitation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In which they dwelt in rest and peace,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nymphs, fawns and hamadryades (wood nymphs);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how the beasts and the birds all<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fled for fear, when the wood was cut down;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how frightened by the light was the ground,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which was not accustomed to see the bright sun;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how the fire was laid first with straw,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And then with dry branches cut in thirds,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And then with green wood and mixtures of spices,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And then with cloth of gold and with precious stones<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And garlands, hanging with full many a flower;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The myrrh, the incense, with such great fragrance;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how Arcite lay among all this,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor what richness about his body is;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how Emelye, as was the custom,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Lighted the fire of funeral service;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how she swooned when men made the fire,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor what she spoke, nor what was her desire;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor what jewels men threw in the fire,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When the fire was great and burned fast;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how some threw their shields, and some their spears,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And of their vestments, which they wore,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And cups full of wine, and milk, and blood,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Into the fire, that burned as if it were mad;<BR>
