&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how the Greeks, with a huge company,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Thrice ride all the fire about<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon the left hand, with a loud shouting,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thrice with their spears clattering;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thrice how the ladies did cry;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And how Emelye was led homeward;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how Arcite is burned to cold ashes;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor how that wake was held  <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All that same night; nor how the Greeks play<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The funeral games I care not to say<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who wrestles best, naked with oil anointed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor who bore him best, in any difficulty.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I will not tell also how they go<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Home to Athens, when the games are done;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But shortly to the point then I will go<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And make an end of my long tale.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By the course of events and by length of a certain number of years,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All stopped is the mourning and the tears<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of the Greeks, by one general assent.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then it seemed to me there was a parliament<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At Athens, upon certain topics and cases;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Among which topics was discussed (a proposal)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To have alliance with certain countries,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And have fully the submission of the Thebans.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which this noble Theseus immediately<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Ordered (someone) to send for gentle Palamon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unknown by him (Palamon) what was the cause and why,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But in his black clothes sorrowfully<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He came at his (Theseus's) commandment in haste.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then Theseus sent for Emelye.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When they were set, and all the place was hushed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And Theseus had waited for a while<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Before any word came from his wise breast,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He set his eyes where his object of desire was.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And with a sad face he sighed softly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after that exactly thus he pronounced his decision:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"The First Mover of the First Cause above,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When he first made the faire chain of love,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Great was the effect, and noble was his plan.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Well knew he why, and what thereof he meant,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For with that faire chain of love he bound<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The fire, the air, the water, and the land<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In definite bounds, from which they may not flee.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That same Prince and that Mover," said he,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Has established in this wretched world below<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Specific (numbers of) days and  (term of) duration<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To all that is engendered in this place,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Beyond the which day they can not pass,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Although they may yet well shorten those days.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There is no need to cite any written authority,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For it is proven by experience,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unless I wish to make my meaning more clear.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then one can by this order well discern<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That that same Mover is stable and eternal.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Well may one know, unless it be a fool,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That every part derives from its whole,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For nature has not taken its beginning<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of no part or portion of a thing,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But of a thing that is complete and stable,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Descending (from that) until it becomes corruptible.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And therefore, by his wise foresight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He has so well established his plan<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That types of being and natural processes<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Shall endure (for a set time) one after another,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And not eternally, without any lie.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This thou canst understand and plainly see.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Lo the oak, that is so slow to mature,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;From the time that it first begins to spring,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And has so long a life, as we may see,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Yet at the last the tree is wasted away.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Consider also how the hard stone<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Under our feet, on which we tread and go,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Eventually it is worn away as it lies by the way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The broad river sometimes grows dry;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;We see the great cities grow weak and pass away.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then you can see that all things have an end.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Of man and woman also we see well <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That by necessity, in one of these two periods of time --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This is to say, in youth or else in age --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He must be dead, the king as must a servant boy;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One in his bed, one in the deep sea,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One in the large field, as people can see;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nothing helps there; all goes that same way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then may I say that all things must die.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"What causes this but Jupiter, the king,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who is prince and cause of all things,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Causing all to return to its own origin<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;From which it is derived, to tell the truth?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And against this no living creature,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of any rank, is helped by striving.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Then is it wisdom, as it seems to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To make virtue of necessity,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And take it well what we may not escape,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And namely that which is due to us all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And whoever complains in any way, he does folly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And is rebel to Him that can rule all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And certainly a man has most honor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To die in his (time of) excellence and flower,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When he is sure of his good name;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then he has not done his friend, nor himself, any shame.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And his friend ought to be more pleased with his death,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When his breath is yielded up with honor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Than when his name is faded because of age,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For all forgotten is his knightly prowess.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then is it best, for a worthy fame,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To die when he has the most fame.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"The contrary of all this is willfulness.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Why do we complain, why do we have sadness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That good Arcite, flower of chivalry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is departed with all due honor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Out of this foul prison of this life?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Why do his cousin and his wife complain here<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of the welfare of him, who loved them so well?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Can he show them his gratitude? Nay, God knows, not a bit;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;They offend both his soul and themselves as well,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And as yet they may not change their desires.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"What  can I conclude of this long argument,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But after woe I advise us to be merry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thank Jupiter for all his grace?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And before we depart from this place<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I advise that we make of two sorrows <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One perfect joy, lasting evermore.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And look now, where most sorrow is herein,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There will we first amend and begin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Sister," said he, "this is my full intention,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With all the advice of my parliament here,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That gentle Palamon, your own knight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who serves you with will, heart, and might,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And ever has done so since you first knew him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That you shall of your grace have pity upon him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And take him for husband and for lord.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Lend me your hand, for this is our decision.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Let your womanly pity now be seen.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He is a king's brother's son, indeed;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And even if he were a poor young knight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Since he has served you so many a year,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And has had for you such great adversity,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It must be taken in account, believe me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For gentle mercy ought to prevail over justice."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then said he thus to Palamon the knight:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"I suppose little preaching is needed here<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To make you assent to this thing.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Come near, and take your lady by the hand."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Between them was made right away the bond<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is called matrimony or marriage,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By all the council and the baronage.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thus with all bliss and festivity<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Palamon has wedded Emelye.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And God, who has made all this wide world,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Send him his love who has dearly paid for it;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For now is Palamon in complete happiness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Living in bliss, in riches, and in health,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And Emelye loves him so tenderly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he serves her so gently,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That never was there any word between them <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of jealousy or any other vexation.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Thus ends Palamon and Emelye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 	&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And God save all this fair company! Amen.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When April with its sweet-smelling showers<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Has pierced the drought of March to the root,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And bathed every vein (of the plants) in such liquid<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By which power the flower is created;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When the West Wind also with its sweet breath,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In every wood and field has breathed life into <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The tender new leaves, and the young sun<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Has run half its course in Aries,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And small fowls make melody,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Those that sleep all the night with open eyes<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(So Nature incites them in their hearts),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then folk long to go on pilgrimages,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And professional pilgrims to seek foreign shores,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To distant shrines, known in various lands;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And specially from every shire's end<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of England to Canterbury they travel,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To seek the holy blessed martyr,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who helped them when they were sick.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It happened that in that season on one day,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In Southwark at the Tabard Inn as I lay<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Ready to go on my pilgrimage<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To Canterbury with a very devout spirit,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At night had come into that hostelry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Well nine and twenty in a company<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of various sorts of people, by chance fallen<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In fellowship, and they were all pilgrims,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who intended to ride toward Canterbury.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The bedrooms and the stables were spacious,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And we were well accommodated in the best way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in brief, when the sun was (gone) to rest,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I had so spoken with everyone of them <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That I was of their fellowship straightway,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And made agreement to rise early,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To take our way where I (will) tell you.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But nonetheless, while I have time and opportunity,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Before I proceed further in this tale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It seems to me in accord with reason<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To tell you all the circumstances<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of each of them, as it seemed to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And who they were, and of what social rank,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also what clothing that they were in;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And at a knight then will I first begin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A KNIGHT there was, and that (one was) a worthy man,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who from the time that he first began<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To ride out, he loved chivalry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Fidelity and good reputation, generosity and courtesy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was very worthy in his lord's war,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And for that he had ridden, no man farther,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As well in Christendom as in heathen lands,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And (was) ever honored for his worthiness;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was at Alexandria when it was won.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had sat very many times in the place of honor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Above (knights of) all nations in Prussia;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had campaigned in Lithuania and in Russia,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;No Christian man of his rank so often.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also he had been in Grenada at the siege <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of Algeciras, and had ridden in Morocco.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was at Ayash and at Atalia,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When they were won, and in the Mediterranean<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had been at many a noble expedition.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had been at fifteen mortal battles,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And fought for our faith at Tlemcen<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Three times in formal duels, and each time slain his foe.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This same worthy knight had also been <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At one time with the lord of Balat<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Against another heathen in Turkey;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And evermore he had an outstanding reputation<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And although he was brave, he was prudent,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And of his deportment as meek as is a maid.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He never yet said any rude word<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all his life unto any sort of person.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a truly perfect, noble knight.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But to tell you of his clothing,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His horses were good, but he was not gaily dressed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He wore a tunic of coarse cloth <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All stained (with rust) by his coat of mail,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he was recently come (back) from his expedition,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And went to do his pilgrimage.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With him there was his son, a young SQUIRE,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A lover and a lively bachelor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With locks curled as if they had been laid in a curler.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was twenty years of age, I guess.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of his stature he was of moderate height,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And wonderfully agile, and of great strength.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he had been for a time on a cavalry expedition<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In Flanders, in Artois, and Picardy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And conducted himself well, for so little a space of time,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In hope to stand in his lady's good graces.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was embroidered, as if it were a mead<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;All full of fresh flowers, white and red.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Singing he was, or fluting, all the day;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was as fresh as is the month of May.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His gown was short, with long and wide sleeves.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to sit on horse and handsomely ride.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew how to make songs and well compose (the words),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Joust and also dance, and well draw and write.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He loved so passionately that at nighttime<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He slept no more than does a nightingale.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Courteous he was, humble, and willing to serve,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And carved before his father at the table.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He (the Knight) had A YEOMAN and no more servants <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At that time, for it pleased him so to travel,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he (the yeoman) was clad in coat and hood of green.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A sheaf of peacock arrows, bright and keen,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He carried under his belt very properly<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(He well knew how to care for his equipment as a yeoman should;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His arrows did not fall short because of drooping feathers),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in his hand he carried a mighty bow.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a close-cropped head, with a brown face.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew all the practice of woodcraft.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He wore an elegant archer's wrist-guard upon his arm,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And by his side a sword and a small shield,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And on that other side an elegant dagger<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Well ornamented and sharp as the point of a spear;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A Christopher-medal of bright silver on his breast.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He carried a horn, the shoulder strap was green;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a forester, truly, as I guess.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was also a Nun, a PRIORESS,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who was very simple and modest in her smiling;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her greatest oath was but by Saint Loy;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And she was called Madam Eglantine.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She sang the divine service very well,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Intoned in her nose in a very polite manner;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And she spoke French very well and elegantly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In the manner of Stratford at the Bow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For French of Paris was to her unknown.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At meals she was well taught indeed;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She let no morsel fall from her lips,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor wet her fingers deep in her sauce;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She well knew how to carry a morsel (to her mouth) and take good care<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That no drop fell upon her breast.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her greatest pleasure was in good manners.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She wiped her upper lip so clean<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That in her cup there was seen no tiny bit <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of grease, when she had drunk her drink.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She reached for her food in a very seemly manner.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And surely she was of excellent deportment,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And very pleasant, and amiable in demeanor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And she took pains to imitate the manners<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of court, and to be dignified in behavior,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to be considered worthy of reverence.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But to speak of her moral sense,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She was so charitable and so compassionate<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She would weep, if she saw a mouse<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Caught in a trap, if it were dead or bled.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had some small hounds that she fed<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With roasted meat, or milk and fine white bread.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But sorely she wept if one of them were dead,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or if someone smote it smartly with a stick;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And all was feeling and tender heart.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her wimple was pleated in a very seemly manner,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her nose well formed, her eyes gray as glass,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her mouth very small, and moreover soft and red.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But surely she had a fair forehead;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It was almost nine inches broad, I believe;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For, certainly, she was not undergrown.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her cloak was very well made , as I was aware.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;About her arm she bore of small coral <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A set of beads, adorned with large green beads,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thereon hung a brooch of very bright gold,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;On which there was first written an A with a crown,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after "Love conquers all."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had another NUN with her,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who was her secretary, and three priests.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a MONK, an extremely fine one,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;An outrider (a monk with business outside the monastery), who loved hunting,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A virile man, qualified to be an abbot.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had very many fine horses in his stable,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And when he rode, one could hear his bridle<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Jingle in a whistling wind as clear<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also as loud as does the chapel belle<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Where this lord was prior of the subordinate monastery.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The rule of Saint Maurus or of Saint Benedict --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Because it was old and somewhat strict<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This same Monk let old things pass away,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And followed the broader customs of modern times.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He gave not a plucked hen for that text<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That says that hunters are not holy men,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor that a monk, when he is heedless of rules,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is like a fish that is out of water --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This is to say, a monk out of his cloister.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But he considered that same text not worth an oyster;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And I said his opinion was good.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Why should he study and make himself crazy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Always to pore upon a book in the cloister,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or work with his hands, and labor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As Augustine commands? How shall the world be served?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Let Augustine have his work reserved to him!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therefore he was indeed a vigorous horseman:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had greyhounds as swift as fowl in flight;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of tracking and of hunting for the hare<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was all his pleasure, by no means would he refrain from it.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I saw his sleeves lined at the hand<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With squirrel fur, and that the finest in the land;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to fasten his hood under his chin,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a very skillfully made pin of gold;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was an elaborate knot in the larger end.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His head was bald, which shone like any glass,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And his face did too, as if he had been rubbed with oil.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a very plump lord and in good condition;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His eyes were prominent, and rolling in his head,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which gleamed like a furnace under a cauldron;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His boots supple, his horse in excellent condition.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now certainly he was a handsome ecclesiastical dignitary;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was not pale as a tormented spirit.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A fat swan loved he best of any roast.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His saddle horse was as brown as is a berry.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a FRIAR, a pleasure-loving and merry one,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A limiter (with an assigned territory), a very solemn man.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all the four orders of friars is no one that knows<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So much of sociability and elegant speech.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had made very many a marriage<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of young women at his own cost.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a noble supporter of his order.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Very well beloved and familiar was he<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With landowners every where in his country,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also with worthy women of the town;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he had power of confession,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As he said himself, more than a parish priest,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he was licensed by his order.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He heard confession very sweetly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And his absolution was pleasant:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a lenient man in giving penance,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Where he knew he would have a good gift.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For to give to a poor order (of friars)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Is a sign that a man is well confessed;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For if he gave, he (the friar) dared to assert,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew that a man was repentant;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For many a man is so hard in his heart,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He can not weep, although he painfully suffers.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therefore instead of weeping and prayers<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One may give silver to the poor friars.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His hood was always stuffed full of knives<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And pins, to give to fair wives.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And certainly he had a merry voice:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to sing and play on a rote (string instrument);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He absolutely took the prize for reciting ballads.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His neck was white as a lily flower;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Furthermore he was strong as a champion fighter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew the taverns well in every town<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And every innkeeper and barmaid<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Better than a leper or a beggar-woman,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For unto such a worthy man as he<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It was not suitable, in view of his official position,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To have acquaintance with sick lepers.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It is not respectable; it can not be profitable,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To deal with any such poor people,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But all with rich people and sellers of victuals.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And every where, where profit should arise,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was courteous and graciously humble;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no man anywhere so capable (of such work).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was the best beggar in his house;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; [And he gave a certain fee for his grant (of begging rights);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; None of his brethren came there in his territory;]<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For though a widow had not a shoe,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So pleasant was his "In the beginning,"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Yet he would have a farthing, before he went away.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His total profit was much more than his proper income.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he knew how to frolic, as if he were indeed a pup.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew how to be much help on days for resolving disputes,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For there he was not like a cloistered monk<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With a threadbare cope, like a poor scholar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But he was like a master of arts or a pope.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of wide (expensive) cloth was his short cloak,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which was round as a bell fresh from the clothespress.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Somewhat he lisped, for his affectation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To make his English sweet upon his tongue;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in his harping, when he had sung,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His eyes twinkled in his head exactly<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As do the stars in the frosty night.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This worthy friar was called Huberd.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a MERCHANT with a forked beard,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Wearing parti-colored cloth, and proudly he sat on his horse;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon his head (he wore a) Flemish beaver hat,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His boots were buckled handsomely and elegantly.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His opinions he spoke very solemnly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Concerning always the increase of his profits.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He wanted the sea to be guarded at all costs<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Between Middelburgh (Holland) and Orwell (England).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to deal in foreign currencies.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This worthy man employed his wit very well:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no one who knew that he was in debt,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was so dignified in managing his affairs<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With his buying and selling and with his financial deals.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Truly, he was a worthy man indeed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But, to say the truth, I do not know what men call him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was also a CLERK (scholar) from Oxford,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who long before had begun the study of logic.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His horse was as lean as is a rake,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he was not very fat, I affirm,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But looked emaciated, and moreover abstemious.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His short overcoat was very threadbare,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he had not yet obtained an ecclesiastical living,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor was he worldly enough to take secular employment.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he would rather have at the head of his bed<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Twenty books, bound in black or red,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of Aristotle and his philosophy<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Than rich robes, or a fiddle, or an elegant psaltery. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But even though he was a philosopher,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nevertheless he had but little gold in his strongbox;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But all that he could get from his friends,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He spent on books and on learning,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And diligently did pray for the souls <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of those who gave him the wherewithal to attend the schools.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He took most care and paid most heed to study.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He spoke not one word more than was needed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And that was said with due formality and respect,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And short and lively and full of elevated content;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His speech was consonant with moral virtue,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And gladly would he learn and gladly teach.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A SERGEANT OF THE LAW (high-ranking attorney), prudent and wise,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who often had been at the Porch of St. Paul's (where lawyers gather)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was also there, very rich in superior qualities.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was judicious and of great dignity --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He seemed such, his words were so wise.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was very often a judge in the court of assizes,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By royal appointment and with full jurisdiction.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For his knowledge and for his excellent reputation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had many grants of yearly income.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was nowhere so great a land-buyer:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In fact, all was unrestricted possession to him;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His purchasing could not be invalidated.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was nowhere so busy a man as he, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And yet he seemed busier than he was.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had in Year Books all the cases and decisions<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That from the time of king William have occurred.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Furthermore, he knew how to compose and draw up a legal document,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So that no one could find a flaw in his writing;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he knew every statute completely by heart.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He rode but simply in a parti-colored coat,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Girded with a belt of silk, with small stripes;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I tell no longer tale of his clothing.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A FRANKLIN was in his company.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His beard was white as a daisy;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As to his temperament, he was dominated by the humor blood.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well loved a bit of bread dipped in wine in the morning;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His custom was always to live in delight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he was Epicurus' own son,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who held the opinion that pure pleasure <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was truly perfect happiness.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a householder, and a great one at that;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was Saint Julian (patron of hospitality) in his country.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His bread, his ale, was always of the same (good) quality;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nowhere was there any man better stocked with wine.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His house was never without baked pies<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of fish and meat, and that so plentiful<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That in his house it snowed with food and drink;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of all the dainties that men could imagine,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In accord with the various seasons of the year,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So he varied his midday meal and his supper.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had very many fat partridges in pens,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And many a bream and many a pike in his fish pond.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Woe was his cook unless his sauce was<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Hotly spiced and sharp, and ready all his cooking equipment.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In his hall his dining table always<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Stood covered (with table cloth) and ready all the long day.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He presided as lord and sire at court sessions;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a member of parliament many times.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A dagger and a purse all of silk<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Hung at his belt, white as morning milk.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had been a sheriff, and an auditor of taxes.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was nowhere such a worthy landowner.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A HABERDASHER and a CARPENTER,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A WEAVER, a DYER, and a TAPESTRY-MAKER --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And they were all clothed in one livery<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of a solemn and a great parish guild.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Their equipment was adorned all freshly and new;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Their knives were not mounted with brass<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But entirely with silver, wrought very neatly and well,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Their belts and their purses every bit.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Each of them well seemed a solid citizen<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To sit on a dais in a city hall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Every one of them, for the wisdom that he knows,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was suitable to be an alderman.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For they had enough possessions and income,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also their wives would well assent to it;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And otherwise certainly they would be to blame.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It is very fine to be called "my lady,"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And go to feasts on holiday eves heading the procession,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And have a gown with a train royally carried.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A COOK they had with them for the occasion<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To boil the chickens with the marrow bones,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And tart poudre-marchant and galingale (spices).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to judge a draft of London ale.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew how to roast, and boil, and broil, and fry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Make stews, and well bake a pie.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But it was a great harm, as it seemed to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That he had an open sore on his shin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As for white pudding, he made that of the best quality.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A SHIPMAN was there, dwelling far in the west;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For all I know, he was from Dartmouth.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He rode upon a cart horse, insofar as he knew how,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In a gown of woolen cloth (that reached) to the knee.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a dagger hanging on a cord <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;About his neck, down under his arm.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The hot summer had made his hue all brown;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And certainly he was a boon companion.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had drawn very many a draft of wine<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;While coming from Bordeaux, while the merchant slept.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had no concern for a scrupulous conscience.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;If he fought and had the upper hand,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He sent them home by water to every land (they walked the plank). <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But of his skill to reckon well his tides,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His currents, and his perils near at hand,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His harbors, and positions of his moon, his navigation,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was none other such from Hull to Cartagena (Spain).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was bold and prudent in his undertakings;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His beard had been shaken by many a tempest.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew all the harbors, how they were,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;From Gotland to the Cape of Finisterre,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And every inlet in Brittany and in Spain.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His ship was called the Maudelayne.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With us there was a DOCTOR OF MEDICINE<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all this world there was no one like him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To speak of medicine and of surgery,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he was instructed in astronomy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He took care of his patient very many times<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In (astronomically suitable) hours by (use of) his natural science.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to calculate the planetary position<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of his astronomical talismans for his patient.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew the cause of every malady,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Were it of hot, or cold, or moist, or dry elements,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And where they were engendered, and by what bodily fluid.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a truly, perfect practitioner:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The cause known, and the source of his (patient's) harm,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Straightway he gave the sick man his remedy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had his apothecaries all ready <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To send him drugs and his electuaries,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For each of them made the other to profit --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Their friendship was not recently begun.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew the old Aesculapius,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And Dioscorides, and also Rufus,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Old Hippocrates, Haly, and Galen,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Serapion, Rhazes, and Avicenna,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Averroes, John the Damascan, and Constantine,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Bernard, and Gaddesden, and Gilbertus.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was moderate in his diet,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For it was of no excess,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But greatly nourishing and digestible.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His study was but little on the Bible.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was clad all in red and in blue,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Lined with taffeta and with silk.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And yet he was moderate in spending;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He kept what he earned in (times of) plague.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Since in medicine gold is a restorative for the heart,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therefore he loved gold in particular.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a good WIFE OF beside BATH,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But she was somewhat deaf, and that was a pity.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had such a skill in cloth-making <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She surpassed them of Ypres and of Ghent.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In all the parish there was no wife <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who should go to the Offering before her;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if there did, certainly she was so angry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That she was out of all charity (love for her neighbor).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her kerchiefs were very fine in texture;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I dare swear they weighed ten pound<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That on a Sunday were upon her head.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Her stockings were of fine scarlet red,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Very closely laced, and shoes very supple and new.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Bold was her face, and fair, and red of hue.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She was a worthy woman all her life:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had (married) five husbands at the church door,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Not counting other company in youth --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But there is no need to speak of that right now.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And she had been three times at Jerusalem;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had passed many a foreign sea;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had been at Rome, and at Boulogne,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In Galicia at Saint-James (of Compostella), and at Cologne.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She knew much about wandering by the way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She had teeth widely set apart, truly to say.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She sat easily upon a pacing horse,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Wearing a large wimple, and on her head a hat<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As broad as a buckler or a shield;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;An overskirt about her large hips,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And on her feet a pair of sharp spurs.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In fellowship she well knew how to laugh and chatter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;She knew, as it happened, about remedies for love <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For she knew the old dance (tricks of the trade) of that art.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A good man was there of religion,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And (he) was a poor PARSON OF A TOWN,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But he was rich in holy thought and work.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was also a learned man, a scholar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who would preach Christ's gospel truly;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would devoutly teach his parishioners.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was gracious, and wonderfully diligent,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And very patient in adversity,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And such he was proven many times.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was very reluctant to excommunicate for (nonpayment of) his tithes,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But rather would he give, there is no doubt,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unto his poor parishioners about<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Some of his offering (received at mass) and also some of his income.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He knew how to have sufficiency in few possessions.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His parish was wide, and houses far apart,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But he did not omit, for rain nor thunder,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In sickness or in trouble to visit<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Those living farthest away in his parish, high-ranking and low,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Going by foot, and in his hand a staff.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He gave this noble example to his sheep,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That first he wrought, and afterward he taught.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He took those words out of the gospel,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And this metaphor he added also to that,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That if gold rust, what must iron do?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For if a priest, on whom we trust, should be foul<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It is no wonder for a layman to go bad;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And it is a shame, if a priest is concerned:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A shit-stained shepherd and a clean sheep.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Well ought a priest to give an example,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By his purity, how his sheep should live.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He did not rent out his benefice (ecclesiastical living)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And leave his sheep encumbered in the mire<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And run to London unto Saint Paul's<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To seek an appointment as a chantry priest (praying for a patron)<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or to be hired (as a chaplain) by a guild;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But dwelt at home, and kept well his sheep fold (parish),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;So that the wolf did not make it go wrong;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a shepherd and not a hireling.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And though he was holy and virtuous,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was not scornful to sinful men,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor domineering nor haughty in his speech,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But in his teaching courteous and kind.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To draw folk to heaven by gentleness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By good example, this was his business.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unless it were an obstinate person,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Whoever he was, of high or low rank,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would rebuke him sharply at that time. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I believe that nowhere is there a better priest.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He expected no pomp and ceremony,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor made himself an overly fastidious conscience,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But Christ's teaching and His twelve apostles <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He taught; but first he followed it himself.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With him there was a PLOWMAN, who was his brother,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who had hauled very many a cartload of dung;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a true and good worker,<BR>
