&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Living in peace and perfect love.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He loved God best with all his whole heart<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At all times, whether it pleased or pained him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And then (he loved) his neighbor exactly as himself.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would thresh, and moreover make ditches and dig,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For Christ's sake, for every poor person,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Without payment, if it lay in his power.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He paid his tithes completely and well,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Both of  his own labor and of his possessions.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He rode in a tabard (sleeveless jacket) upon a mare.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was also a REEVE, and a MILLER,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A SUMMONER, and a PARDONER also,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A MANCIPLE, and myself -- there were no more.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The MILLER was a stout fellow indeed;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was very strong of muscle, and also of bones.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That was well proven, for wherever he came,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At wrestling he would always take the the prize.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was stoutly built, broad, a large-framed fellow;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no door that he would not heave off its hinges,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or break it by running at it with his head.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His beard was red as any sow or fox,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And moreover broad, as though it were a spade.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon the exact top of his nose he had<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A wart, and thereon stood a tuft of hairs,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Red as the bristles of a sow's ears;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His nostrils were black and wide.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He wore a sword and a buckler by his side.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His mouth was as large as a large furnace.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a loudmouth and a buffoon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And that was mostly of sin and deeds of harlotry.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to steal corn and take payment three times;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And yet he had a thumb of gold, indeed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He wore a white coat and a blue hood.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to blow and play a bag-pipe,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And with that he brought us out of town.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a fine MANCIPLE of a temple (law school),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of whom buyers of provisions might take example<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For how to be wise in buying of victuals;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For whether he paid (cash) or took (goods) on credit,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Always he watched so (carefully for his opportunity) in his purchases<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That he was always ahead and in good state.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now is not that a very fair grace of God <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That such an unlearned man's wit shall surpass<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The wisdom of a heap of learned men?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had more than three times ten masters,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who were expert and skillful in law,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of whom there were a dozen in that house<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Worthy to be stewards of rent and land<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of any lord that is in England,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To make him live by his own wealth<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In honor and debtless (unless he were crazy),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or live as economically as it pleased him to desire;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And (they would be) able to help all a shire<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In any emergency that might occur or happen.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And yet this Manciple fooled them all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The REEVE was a slender choleric man.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His beard was shaved as close as ever he can;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His hair was closely cropped by his ears;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The top of his head in front was cut short like a priest's.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His legs were very long and very lean,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Like a stick; there was no calf to be seen.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to keep a granary and a storage bin;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no auditor who could earn anything (by catching him).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew by the drought and by the rain<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(What would be) the yield of his seed and of his grain.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His lord's sheep, his cattle, his herd of dairy cows,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His swine, his horses, his livestock, and his poultry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Was wholly in this Reeve's control,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in accord with his contract he gave the reckoning,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Since his lord was twenty years of age.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no man who could find him in arrears.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no farm manager, nor herdsman, nor other servant,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Whose trickery and treachery he did not know;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;They were afraid of him as of the plague.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His dwelling was very nicely situated upon an heath;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;His place was shaded by green trees.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He could buy property better than his lord could.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was secretly very richly provided.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to please his lord subtly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By giving and lending him some of his lord's own possessions,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And have thanks, and also a coat and hood (as a reward).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In youth he had learned a good craft:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a very good craftsman, a carpenter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This Reeve sat upon a very good horse<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That was all dapple gray and was called Scot.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had on a long outer coat of dark blue,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And by his side he wore a rusty sword.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of Northfolk was this Reeve of whom I tell,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Near to a town men call Bawdeswelle.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had his coat hitched up and belted, like a friar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And ever he rode as the last of our company.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was a SUMMONER with us in that place,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who had a fire-red cherubim's face,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For it was pimpled and discolored, with swollen eyelids.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was as hot and lecherous as a sparrow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With black, scabby brows and a beard with hair fallen out.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Children were afraid of his face.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no mercury, lead monoxide, nor sulphur,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Borax, white lead, nor any oil of tarter,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor ointment that would cleanse and burn,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That could cure him of his white pustules,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor of the knobs sitting on his cheeks.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well loved garlic, onions, and also leeks,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to drink strong wine, red as blood;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then he would speak and cry out as if he were crazy.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And when he had drunk deeply of the wine,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Then he would speak no word but Latin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a few legal terms, two or three,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That he had learned out of some text of ecclesiastical law --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is no wonder, he heard it all the day;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And also you know well how a jay<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Can call out "Walter" as well as the pope can.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But whoever knew how to examine him in other matters,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(Would find that) he had used up all his learning;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Always "The question is, what point of the law applies?" he would cry.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a fine rascal and a kind one;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;One could not find a better fellow.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For a quart of wine he would allow<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A good fellow to have his concubine<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For twelve months, and excuse him completely;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Secretly he also knew how to pull off a clever trick.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if he found anywhere a good fellow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He would teach him to have no awe<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of the archdeacon's curse (of excommunication) in such a case,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unless a man's soul were in his purse;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For in his purse he would be punished.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Purse is the archdeacon's hell," he said.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But well I know he lied right certainly;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Each guilty man ought to be afraid of excommunication,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For excommunication will slay just as forgiveness saves,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And let him also beware of a Significavit (order for imprisonment).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In his control he had as he pleased<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The young people of the diocese,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And knew their secrets, and was the adviser of them all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had set a garland upon his heed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As large as if it were for the sign of a tavern<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had made himself a shield of a cake.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With him there rode a fine PARDONER<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Of Rouncivale, his friend and his companion,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Who had come straight from the court of Rome.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Very loud he sang "Come hither, love, to me!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This Summoner harmonized with him in a strong bass;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was never a trumpet of half so great a sound.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This Pardoner had hair as yellow as wax,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But smooth it hung as does a clump of flax;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By small strands hung such locks as he had,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he spread them over his shoulders;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But thin it lay, by strands one by one.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But to make an attractive appearance, he wore no hood,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For it was trussed up in his knapsack.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It seemed to him that he rode in the very latest style;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With hair unbound, save for his cap, he rode all bare-headed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had glaring eyes such as has a hare.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had sewn a Veronica upon his cap.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Before him in his lap, (he had) his knapsack, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Brimful of pardons come all fresh from Rome.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a voice as small as a goat has.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had no beard, nor never would have;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It (his face) was as smooth as if it were recently shaven.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I believe he was a eunuch or a homosexual.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But as to his craft, from Berwick to Ware<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no other pardoner like him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For in his pouch he had a pillow-case,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Which he said was Our Lady's veil;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He said he had a piece of the sail<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That Saint Peter had, when he went<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Upon the sea, until Jesus Christ took him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He had a cross of latten (brass-like alloy) covered with stones,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And in a glass container he had pigs' bones.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But with these relics, when he found<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;A poor parson dwelling in the countryside,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In one day he got himself more money<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Than the parson got in two months;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thus, with feigned flattery and tricks,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He made fools of the parson and the people.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But truly to tell at the last,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was in church a noble ecclesiast.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He well knew how to read a lesson or a story,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But best of all he sang an Offertory;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For he knew well, when that song was sung,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He must preach and well smooth his speech<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To win silver, as he very well knew how; <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Therefore he sang the more merrily and loud.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now have I told you truly, briefly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The rank, the dress, the number, and also the cause<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Why this company was assembled <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In Southwark at this fine hostelry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is called the Tabard, close by the Bell.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But now it is time to tell to you <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;How we conducted ourselves that same night,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When we had arrived in that hostelry;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after that I will tell of our journey<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And all the rest of our pilgrimage.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But first I pray yow, of your courtesy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That you do not attribute it to my rudeness,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Though I speak plainly in this matter,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To tell you their words and their behavior,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Nor though I speak their words accurately.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For this you know as well as I:<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Whoever must repeat a story after someone,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He must repeat as closely as ever he knows how<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Every single word, if it be in his power,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Although he may speak ever so rudely and freely,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or else he must tell his tale inaccurately,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Or make up things, or find new words.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He may not refrain from (telling the truth), although he were his brother;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He must as well say one word as another.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Christ himself spoke very plainly in holy writ,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And you know well it is no rudeness.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also Plato says, whosoever knows how to read him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The words must be closely related to the deed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also I pray you to forgive it to me,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Although I have not set folk in order of their rank<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Here in this tale, as they should stand.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;My wit is short, you can well understand.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Our Host made great hospitality to everyone of us,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to the supper he set us straightway.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He served us with victuals of the best sort;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The wine was strong, and it well pleased us to drink.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;OUR HOST was an impressive man indeed<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;(Qualified) to be a master of ceremonies in a hall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He was a large man with prominent eyes --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;There was no better business man in Cheapside --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Bold of his speech, and wise, and well mannered,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he lacked nothing at all of the qualities proper to a man.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Also moreover he was a right merry man;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And after supper he began to be merry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And spoke of mirth among other things,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When we had paid our bills,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And said thus: "Now, gentlemen, truly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;You are right heartily welcome to me;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For by my word, if I shall not lie (I must say),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I saw not this year so merry a company<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;At one time in this lodging as is (here) now.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I would gladly make you happy, if I knew how.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And I have just now thought of an amusement,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To give you pleasure, and it shall cost nothing.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"You go to Canterbury -- God give you success,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;May the blessed martyr give you your reward!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And well I know, as you go by the way,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;You intend to tell tales and to amuse yourselves;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For truly, it is no comfort nor mirth<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To ride by the way dumb as a stone;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And therefore I will make a game for you,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As I said before, and provide you some pleasure.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if pleases you all unanimously<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To be subject to my judgment,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to do as I shall tell you,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Tomorrow, when you ride by the way,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now, by the soul of my father who is dead,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unless you be merry, I will give you my head!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Hold up your hands, without more speech."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Our decision was not long to seek out.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;It seemed to us it was not worthwhile to deliberate on it,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And (we) granted his request without more discussion,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And asked him to say his decision as it pleased him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;"Gentlemen," said he, "now listen for the best course of action;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;But, I pray yow, do not take it in disdain (scorn it).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This is the point, to speak briefly and clearly,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That each of yow, to make our way seem short by this means,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Must tell two tales in this journey<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;On the way to Canterbury, that is what I mean,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And on the homeward trip he shall tell two others,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;About adventures that in old times have happened.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And whoever of you who does best of all --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That is to say, who tells in this case<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Tales of best moral meaning and most pleasure --<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Shall have a supper at the cost of us all<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Here in this place, sitting by this post,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;When we come back from Canterbury.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And to make you the more merry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;I will myself gladly ride with you,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Entirely at my own cost, and be your guide;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And whosoever will not accept my judgment <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Shall pay all that we spend by the way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And if you grant that it be so,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Tell me straightway, without more words,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And I will get ready early for this."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;This thing was granted, and our oaths sworn<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;With very glad hearts, and (we) prayed him also<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;That he would consent to do so,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And that he would be our governor,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And judge and score keeper of our tales,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And set a supper at a certain price,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And we will be ruled as he wishes<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In every respect; and thus unanimously<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;We are accorded to his judgment.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And thereupon the wine was fetched immediately;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;We drank, and each one went to rest,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Without any longer tarrying.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;In the morning, when day began to spring,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Our Host arose, and was the rooster of us all (awakened us).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And gathered us together all in a flock,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And forth we rode at little more than a walk<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Unto the Watering of Saint Thomas;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And there our Host stopped his horse<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And said, "Gentlemen, listen, if you please.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;You know your agreement, and I remind you of it.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;If what you said last night agrees with what you say this morning, <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Let's see now who shall tell the first tale.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As ever I may drink wine or ale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Whosoever may be rebel to my judgment<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Shall pay for all that is spent by the way.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now draw straws, before we depart further (from London);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He who has the shortest shall begin.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Sir Knight," said he, "my master and my lord,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now draw a straw, for that is my decision.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Come nearer," he said, "my lady Prioress.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And you, sir Clerk, let be your modesty,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And study not; lay hand to (draw a straw), every man!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Every person began straightway to draw,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And shortly to tell as it was,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Were it by chance, or destiny, or luck,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;The truth is this: the draw fell to the Knight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;For which everyone was very happy and glad,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he must tell his tale, as was reasonable,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;By our previous promise and by formal agreement,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;As you have heard; what more words are needed?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And when this good man saw that it was so,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Like one who was wise and obedient<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To keep his agreement by his free assent,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;He said, "Since I must begin the game,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;What! Welcome be the draw, in God's name!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;Now let us ride, and listen to what I say."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And with that word we rode forth on our way,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;And he began with a truly merry demeanor<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; <nobr>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;To tell his tale straightway, and said as you may hear.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When the Knight had thus told his tale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In all the company there was no one young nor old<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who did not say it was a noble story<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And worthy to draw into memory,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And especially the gentlefolk every one.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Our Host laughed and swore, "As I may move about (I swear),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This goes well; the bag is opened.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Let's see now who shall tell another tale;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For truly the game is well begun.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Now tell you, sir Monk, if you can,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Something to equal the Knight's tale."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The Miller, who for drunkenness was all pale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So that he hardly sat upon his horse,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He would not doff neither hood nor hat,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nor give preference to any man out of courtesy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But in Pilate's voice he began to cry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And swore, "By (Christ's) arms, and by blood and bones,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I know a noble tale for this occasion,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; With which I will now requite the Knight's tale."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Our Host saw that he was drunk on ale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Wait, Robin, my dear brother;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Some better man shall first tell us another.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Wait, and let us act properly."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "By God's soul," said he, "that will not I;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For I will speak or else go my way."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Our Host answered, "Tell on, in the devil's name!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou art a fool; thy wit is overcome."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Now listen," said the Miller, "everyone!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But first I make a protestation<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That I am drunk; I know it by my sound.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And therefore if that I misspeak or say (amiss),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Blame it on ale of Southwerk, I you pray.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For I will tell a legend and a life<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Both of a carpenter and of his wife,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; How a clerk has set the carpenter's cap (fooled him)."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The Reeve answered and said, "Hold your tongue!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Let be thy ignorant drunken ribaldry.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It is a sin and also a great folly<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To slander any man, or defame him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And also to bring wives in such ill fame.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou canst say enough about other things."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This drunken Miller spoke very quickly in reply<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Dear brother Oswald,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He who has no wife, he is no cuckold.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But I say not therefore that thou art one;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There are very good wives, many a one,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And ever a thousand good against one bad.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Thou knowest that well thyself, unless thou art mad.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Why art thou angry with my tale now?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I have a wife, by God, as well as thou;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Yet I would not, for the oxen in my plow,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Take upon me more than enough (trouble),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As to believe of myself that I were one (a cuckold);<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I will believe well that I am not one.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A husband must not be inquisitive<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of God's secrets, nor of his wife.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So long as he can find God's plenty there,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of the rest he needs not enquire."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; What more should I say, but this Miller<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He would not refrain from speaking for any man,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But told his churl's tale in his manner.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I regret that I must repeat it here.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And therefore every respectable person I pray,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For God's love, think not that I speak<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Out of evil intention, but because I must repeat<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; All their tales, be they better or worse,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or else (I must) falsify some of my material.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And therefore, whoever does not want to hear it,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Turn over the leaf and choose another tale;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For he shall find enough, of every sort,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of historical matter that concerns nobility,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And also morality and holiness.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Blame not me if you choose amiss.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The Miller is a churl; you know this well.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So was the Reeve also and many others,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And ribaldry they told, both of the two.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Think about this, and don't blame me;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And also people should not take a joke too seriously.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There was once dwelling at Oxford<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A rich churl, who took in boarders,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And of his craft he was a carpenter.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; With him there was dwelling a poor scholar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who had learned the arts curriculum, but all his desire<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Was turned to learning astrology,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he knew a certain (number of) of astronomical operations,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To determine by scientific calculations,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; If men asked him, in specific (astronomical) hours<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When men should have drought or else showers,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or if people asked him what should happen<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Concerning every thing; I can not reckon them all.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This clerk was called clever Nicholas.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of secret love he knew and of its satisfaction;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And moreover he was sly and very discreet,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And like a maiden meek in appearance.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A room had he in that hostelry<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Alone, without any company,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very elegantly strewn with sweet-smelling herbs;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he himself as sweet as is the root<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of licorice or any zedoary (a ginger-like herb).<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His Almagest, and books large and small,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His astrolabe, belonging to his art (of astronomy),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His counting stones (for his abacus) lie neatly apart,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Arranged on shelves at his bed's head;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His linen press covered with a red woolen cloth;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And all above there lay a fine psaltery,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; On which at night he made melody<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So sweetly that all the room rang;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And "The Angel to the Virgin" he sang;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And after that he sang the King's Tune.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very often his merry throat was blessed.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And thus this sweet clerk spent his time <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Living on his friends' support and his (own) income.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This carpenter had recently wedded a wife,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Whom he loved more than his life;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She was eighteen years of age.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Jealous he was, and held her narrowly in confinement,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For she was wild and young, and he was old<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And believed himself likely to be a cuckold.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He knew not Cato, for his wit was rude,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who advised that man should wed his equal.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Men should wed according to their status in life,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For youth and old age are often in conflict.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But since he was fallen in the snare,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He must endure, like other folk, his troubles.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Fair was this young wife, and moreover<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As any weasel was her body graceful and slender.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A belt she wore, with decorative strips all of silk,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; An apron as white as morning milk<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Upon her loins, full of many a flounce.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; White was her smock, and embroidered all in front<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And also behind, around her collar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; With coal-black silk, within and also without.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The ribbons of her white cap<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Were of the same color as her collar;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Her headband broad of silk, and set very high.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And surely she had a wanton eye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Her two eyebrows were plucked very thin,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And those were bent and black as any sloe.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She was much more blissful to look upon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than is the new early-ripe pear tree,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And softer than the wool is of a sheep.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And by her girdle hung a purse of leather,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Tasseled with silk and ornamented with latten "pearls."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In all this world, to seek up and down,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; There is no man so wise that he could imagine<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So lovely a little doll or such a wench.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Much brighter was the shining of her complexion<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Than the newly minted noble in the Tower.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But of her song, it was as loud and lively<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As any swallow sitting on a barn.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Moreover she could skip and play,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Like any kid or calf following its mother.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Her mouth was sweet as ale and honey or mead,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or a hoard of apples laid in hay or heather.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Skittish she was, as is a spirited colt,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Tall as a mast, and straight as an arrow.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A brooch she wore upon her low collar,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As broad as is the boss of a shield.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Her shoes were laced high on her legs.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She was a primrose, a pig's eye (a flower),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For any lord to lay in his bed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or yet for any good yeoman to wed.   <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Now, sir, and again, sir, it so happened<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That one day this clever Nicholas<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Happened with this young wife to flirt and play,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; While her husband was at Oseneye,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For clerks are very subtle and very clever;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And intimately he caught her by her crotch,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Indeed, unless I have my will,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For secret love of thee, sweetheart, I die."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And held her hard by the thigh,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Sweetheart, love me immediately<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or I will die, so save me God!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And she sprang as a colt does when restrained,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And with her head she twisted fast away,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "I will not kiss thee, by my faith!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Why, let me be!" said she. "Let me be, Nicholas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Or I will cry `out, help' and `alas'!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Take away your hands, for your courtesy!"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This Nicholas began to cry for mercy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And spoke so fair, and pressed his suit so fast,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That she granted him her love at the last,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And swore her oath, by Saint Thomas of Kent,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That she will be at his commandment,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When she may well espy her opportunity.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "My husband is so full of jealousy<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That unless you wait patiently and are secretive,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I know right well I am as good as dead," said she.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "You must been very secret in this matter."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "No, care thee not about that," said Nicholas.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "A clerk had badly wasted his time (studying),<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; If he could not outwit a carpenter."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And thus they are agreed and sworn<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To wait for a time, as I have told before.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; When Nicholas had done thus every bit<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And well patted her about the loins,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He kissed her sweetly and takes his psaltery,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And plays fast, and makes melody.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Then it thus happened, that to the parish church,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Christ's own works to do,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This good wife went on a holiday.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Her forehead shone as bright as any day,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; It was so washed when she left her work.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Now was there of that church a parish clerk,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who was called Absolon.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Curly was his hair, and as the gold it shone,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And stretched out like a fan large and broad;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very straight and even lay his elegant parted hair.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His complexion was ruddy, his eyes gray as a goose.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; With St. Paul's window carved on his shoes,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In red hose he went elegantly.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Clad he was very trimly and properly<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; All in a tunic of a light blue;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very fair and thick are the laces set.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And over that he had a gay surplice<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As white as is the blossom upon the branch.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A merry lad he was, so save me God.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Well could he draw blood, and cut hair and shave,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And make a charter of land or a legal release. <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In twenty different ways could he trip and dance<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; After the school of Oxford as it was then,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And with his legs kick to and fro,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And play songs on a small fiddle,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To which he some times sang a loud high treble;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he could play as well on a guitar.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In all the town there was no brew house nor tavern<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That he did not visit with his entertainment,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Where any merry barmaid was.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But to say the truth, he was somewhat squeamish<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; About farting, and fastidious in his speech.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This Absolon, who was elegant and gay,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Goes with a censer on the holiday,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Censing the wives of the parish eagerly;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And many a lovely look he cast on them,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And especially on this carpenter's wife.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To look on her he thought a merry life,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She was so attractive and sweet and flirtatious.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I dare well say, if she had been a mouse,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And he a cat, he would have grabbed her at once.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This parish clerk, this elegant Absolon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Has in his heart such a love-longing<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That of no wife took he any offering;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For courtesy, he said, he would have none.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The moon, when it was night, very brightly shone,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And Absolon his guitar has taken;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For the sake of love he intended to stay awake.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And forth he goes, elegant and amorous,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Until he came to the carpenter's house<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A little after cocks had crowed,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And took his place up by a casement window<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That was upon the carpenter's wall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He sings in his voice gentle and high,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Now, dear lady, if it be thy will,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I pray yow that you will have pity on me,"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very well in harmony with his guitar-playing.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This carpenter awoke, and heard him sing,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And spoke unto his wife, and said at once,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "What! Alison! Hearest thou not Absolon,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That chants thus next to our bedroom's wall?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And she answered her husband immediately,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Yes indeed, God knows, John, I hear it every bit."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This goes on; what more would you have?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; From day to day this elegant Absolon<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So woos her that he is in a sorry state.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He stays awake all the night and all the day;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He combs his flowing locks, and dressed himself elegantly;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He woos her by go-betweens and agents,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And swore he would be her own servant;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He sings, trilling like a nightingale;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He sent her sweetened wine, mead, and spiced ale,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And wafers, piping hot out of the fire;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And, because she was a townie, he offered money;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For some folk will be won for riches,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And some by force, and some for noble character.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Sometimes, to show his agility and skill,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He plays Herod upon a high stage.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But what good does it do him in this case?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She so loves this clever Nicholas<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That Absolon may go whistle;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He had for his labor nothing but scorn.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And thus she makes Absolon her fool,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And turns all his earnestness into a joke.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Very true is this proverb, it is no lie,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Men say right thus: "Always the nearby sly one<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Makes the distant loved one to be disliked."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For though Absolon be crazed or angry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Because he was far from her sight,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This nearby Nicholas cast him in the shadow.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Now bear thyself well, thou clever Nicholas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For Absolon may wail and sing "alas."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And so it happened on a Saturday,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This carpenter was gone to Osenay;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And clever Nicholas and Alisoun<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Are agreed on this plan,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That Nicholas shall devise a trick<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; To beguile this hapless jealous husband;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And if it so be the game went right,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She should sleep in his arms all night,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; For this was his desire and hers also.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And right away, without more words,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This Nicholas no longer would tarry,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But has carried very quietly unto his chamber<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Both food and drink for a day or two,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And told her to say to her husband,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; If he asked about Nicholas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She should say she knew not where he was;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Of all that day she saw him not with eye;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; She believed that he was ill,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Because, for no shout could her maid call him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He would not answer for anything that might befall.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This goes on all that same Saturday,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That Nicholas still in his chamber lay,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And ate and slept, or did what he pleased,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Until Sunday, when the sun goes to rest.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This hapless carpenter has great marvel<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; About Nicholas, or what thing might ail him,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "I am afraid, by Saint Thomas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Things are not right with Nicholas.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; God forbid that he should suddenly die!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This world is now very ticklish, surely.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I saw today a corpse carried to church<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; That just now, on last Monday, I saw him work.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Go up," he said unto his servant at once,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "Call at his door, or knock with a stone.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Look how it is, and tell me quickly."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This servant goes up very resolutely,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And at the chamber door while he stood,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He cried and knocked as if he were crazy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; "What, hey! What do you, master Nicholay?<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; How can you sleep all the long day?"<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; But all for naught; he heard not a word.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He found a hole, very low upon a board,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Where the cat was accustomed to creep in,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And through that hole he looked in very carefully,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And at the last he had a sight of him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This Nicholas sat ever gaping upward,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As if he were gazing on the new moon.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Down he goes, and told his master immediately<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In what condition he saw this same man.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This carpenter began to bless himself,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And said, "Help us, Saint Frideswide!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; A man knows little what shall happen to him.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This man is fallen, because of his astronomy,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In some madness or in some fit.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I always thought well how it should be!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Men should not know of God's secrets.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Yes, blessed be always an unlearned man<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Who knows nothing but only his belief!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; So fared another clerk with astronomy;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He walked in the fields to look <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Upon the stars, (to find) there what should happen,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Until he was fallen in a fertilizer pit;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He did not see that. But yet, by Saint Thomas,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; I feel very sorry for clever Nicholas.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He shall be scolded for his studying,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; If that I may, by Jesus, heaven's king!<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Get me a staff, that I may pry up from below,   <BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; While thou, Robyn, lift up the door.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; He shall (come) out of his studying, as I guess."<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And to the chamber door he turned his attention.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; His servant was a strong fellow for this purpose,<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; And by the hasp he heaved it off at once;<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Onto the floor the door fell straightway.<BR>
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; This Nicholas sat ever as still as stone,<BR>
